# character-combo-finder
Ya know those memes where they take a scene from a movie with subtitles (usually a common meme template one) and blank out characters to make something else? Like [this](https://www.reddit.com/r/PrequelMemes/comments/cknx1p/apple/)


![So this is how ~~l~~i~~berty~~ die~~s~~. With ~~thunderous~~ appl~~aus~~e](https://preview.redd.it/j8xlywrm2ud31.jpg?width=640&crop=smart&auto=webp&s=1761ae3bd1c8447f67a781f410f648bb789fc801)

Well I was trying to make those with my friend a couple days ago and I had the bright idea to write a program to find every possible permutation of blanked and non-blanked characters for a string of text to make finding these easier. main.py is the original code I threw together in like 20 minutes, I might add a couple other versions I and others came up with later. Also, it doesn't actually work as an effective way to find those meme combinations because it either moves too fast to read and if you use something too long you wont be able to view most of the output because terminals will get rid of old output at a certain point or you put a pause and it ends up taking forever. A 2.5 second delay feels like it will take forever and a 0.5 second delay makes it take hours. You can speed up the program by A LOT by not printing (but that doesn't get us much) or by holding what you are going to print in a buffer (but be careful about memory and it makes the code less clean). I think this code demonstrates well how quickly you can write elegant and expressive code with Python but I could honestly probably whip something up to do the same thing in C++ fairly quickly. Might not look as elegant, probably would by more performant tho. Either way, this was a nice way to learn how to use bitwise operators in python. Welp, I'm off to try to run the bee movie script through it... If you don't hear from me again then my computer has finally gotten pissed enough to try to kill me and take my identity 01101000 01101100 01100101 01110000 00100000 01101001 00100111 01101101 # Special Thanks
A big special thanks to SpaceOwl17 and jesse-toftum for listening to me talk about my weird obsession with this little bit of code as I run things through it and helping me test and optimize it
# Fun Math
- Storing all the results from a 36 character long input string back-to-back would take more than 1TB
- The newlines in newline seperating all the results of a 40 character long string would take more than 1TB (funny way of saying there would be over a trillion results)
- A string 266 characters long would generate more characters for the combinations than ATOMS IN THE UNIVERSE (10^82)
